skeptics.name: Niels van der Linden
skeptics.title: Amateur economist, VforVoluntary.com
skeptics.article: Don't Buy Bitcoins

skeptics.name: Peter Schiff
skeptics.title: CEO, Euro Pacific Capital, Inc.
skeptics.article: Peter Schiff Radio Show with Bitcoin
skeptics.excerpt: What [bitcoins] lack is their own fundamental intrinsic value. You can’t do anything with a bitcoin, other than trade it for something you want. So, intrinsically, the bitcoin itself has no value. It only has value as a medium of exchange so long as people are willing to accept it.

skeptics.name: Adrian Covert
skeptics.title: Journalist
skeptics.article: The Bitcoin Is Dying
skeptics.excerpt: The lulz were abundant. But frankly, it’s time for you to go. Farewell.

skeptics.name: Michael Calore
skeptics.title: Journalist
skeptics.article: Wired, Tired, Expired for 2012: From Stellar to Suck
skeptics.excerpt: Then came the malware, the black market, the legal ambiguities and The Man. Today, you can't even use it to buy Facebook stock

skeptics.name: Tim Worstall
skeptics.title: Journalist
skeptics.article: So, That's the End of Bitcoin Then
skeptics.excerpt: It’s difficult to see what the currency has going for it.

skeptics.name: Patrik Korda
skeptics.title: Amateur trader
skeptics.article: Bitcoin Bubble 2.0
skeptics.excerpt: Thus, we have an answer before us: bitcoins are fiduciary media, or more specifically token money. From a monetary standpoint, as devised and formulated by Ludwig von Mises, they are on a par with the stuff you find at Chuck E. Cheese's.

skeptics.name: Heidi Moore
skeptics.title: Finance and Economics Editor, The Guardian US
skeptics.article: Confused about Bitcoin? It's 'the Harlem Shake of currency'
skeptics.excerpt: Of course, in a rational world, none of that will be written, except perhaps as satire. Bitcoin's crash is less of a currency crisis than an opportune moment for internet wisecracks.

skeptics.name: Robert McMillan
skeptics.title: Journalist
skeptics.article: Watch Wired Get Rich Quick With Our Sleek Bitcoin Miner
skeptics.excerpt: But in the end, the answer was obvious. The world’s most popular digital currency really is nothing more than an abstraction. So we’re destroying the private key used by our Bitcon wallet.

skeptics.name: Ian Bremmer
skeptics.title: Founder and President, Eurasia Group
skeptics.article: Strategist predicts end of Bitcoin
skeptics.excerpt: "I would be very surprised if Bitcoin is still around in 10 years," said Bremmer, the founder and CEO of Eurasia Group, the world's largest risk consulting firm. He thinks that bigger players will enter the field and improve upon Bitcoin's weaknesses.

skeptics.name: Kurt Eichenwald
skeptics.title: Contributing editor, Vanity Fair
skeptics.article: The Logic Problems That Will Eventually Pop the Bitcoin Bubble
skeptics.excerpt: So, anyone out there buying Bitcoins at ridiculously inflated prices, please recognize the risk you are taking. You will likely lose everything.

skeptics.name: David S. Evans
skeptics.title: Chairman of the Global Economics Group
skeptics.article: Bitcoin is a Remarkable Innovation, Here's Why It Will Fail
skeptics.excerpt: I think there are two realistic directions the bitcoin ecosystem could go in. First, it could just implode and disappear if governments decide that virtual currencies cause too much harm and are too hard to regulate. Long-term investments in bitcoin would then go up in smoke. Second, it could continue as a virtual currency that is only used on the dark web with exchanges that are run by people willing to break the laws. The value of bitcoin would decline to whatever the illegal sector could support; regular investors wouldn’t be able to get their value from bitcoin unless they cashed it in with someone who wanted to do bad things.

skeptics.name: Joseph Weisenthal
skeptics.title: Executive Editor, Business Insider
skeptics.article: Bitcoin Is A Joke
skeptics.excerpt: Bitcoin? Nada. There's nothing keeping it being a thing. If people lose faith in it, it's over. Bitcoin is fiat currency in the most literal sense of the word.

skeptics.name: Matthew O'Brien
skeptics.title: Journalist
skeptics.article: Bitcoin Is the Segway of Currency
skeptics.excerpt: In other words, Bitcoin is a Ponzi scheme libertarians use to make money off each other—because gold wasn't enough of one for them.

skeptics.name: Gary North
skeptics.title: Economist
skeptics.article: Bitcoins: The Second Biggest Ponzi Scheme in History
skeptics.excerpt: Bitcoins will never achieve this. It is a mania going up. It will be a mania coming down. It will not increase the division of labor, because people will recognize it as having been a Ponzi scheme, and they will not again buy it. They will not use it in exchange. Companies will not sell goods and services based on Bitcoins. Bitcoins have to have stable purchasing power if they are to serve as money, and they will never, ever achieve stable purchasing power.

skeptics.name: Matthew Yglesias
skeptics.title: Executive Editor, Vox
skeptics.article: Why I Haven't Changed My Mind About Bitcoin
skeptics.excerpt: My primary interest in Bitcoin is that I think it's a great platform for making jokes.

skeptics.name: Mark T. Williams
skeptics.title: Finance Professor, Boston University
skeptics.article: Beware of Bitcoin
skeptics.excerpt: Once sellers outnumber buyers, prices will eventually drop below $10, erasing all gains. This price collapse will occur by the first half of 2014.

skeptics.name: Alex Payne
skeptics.title: Developer and Angel Investor
skeptics.article: Bitcoin, Magical Thinking, and Political Ideology
skeptics.excerpt: Bitcoin represents more of the same short-sighted hypercapitalism that got us into this mess, minus the accountability.

skeptics.name: Charlie Stross
skeptics.title: Author
skeptics.article: Why I want Bitcoin to die in a fire
skeptics.excerpt: TL:DR; the current banking industry and late-period capitalism may suck, but replacing it with Bitcoin would be like swapping out a hangnail for Fournier's gangrene.

skeptics.name: Edward Hadas
skeptics.title: Economics Editor, Reuters
skeptics.article: Bitcoin Mania Heads Into the Endgame
skeptics.excerpt: The electronic pseudocurrency has had a good run. Ideologues, speculators and scammers enjoyed the fun while it lasted. But now that the authorities are taking notice, the price has much further to fall.

skeptics.name: Brad DeLong
skeptics.title: Professor of Economics, U.C. Berkeley
skeptics.article: Watching Bitcoin, Dogecoin, Etc...
skeptics.excerpt: You can either work doing something useful, or you can set up a botnet to mine BitCoins, or you can fork the code behind BitCoin and set up your own slightly-tweaked virtual cryptographic money network. Setting up a new, alternative network is really cheap. Thus unless BitCoin going can somehow successfully differentiate itself from the latecomers who are about to emerge, the money supply of BitCoin-like things is infinite because the cost of production of them is infinitesimal.

skeptics.name: Paul Krugman
skeptics.title: Nobel Prize-winning Economist
skeptics.article: Bitcoin is Evil
skeptics.excerpt: So far almost all of the Bitcoin discussion has been positive economics — can this actually work? And I have to say that I’m still deeply unconvinced. To be successful, money must be both a medium of exchange and a reasonably stable store of value. And it remains completely unclear why BitCoin should be a stable store of value.

skeptics.name: Lisa Kramer
skeptics.title: "Serious Economist"
skeptics.article: Bursting the bitcoin bubble
skeptics.excerpt: As a Serious Economist, I had been happily ignoring the recent bitcoin frenzy, safe in the smug knowledge shared by all Serious Economists that the surge in bitcoin value is a bubble that will soon pop.

skeptics.name: Jamie Dimon
skeptics.title: President & CEO, JPMorgan Chase
skeptics.article: Dimon Disses Bitcoin, and Bitcoiners Diss Back
skeptics.excerpt: "It’s a terrible store of value," Mr. Dimon said in an interview with CNBC. "It could be replicated over and over."

skeptics.name: Paul Singer
skeptics.title: CEO, Elliott Management Corporation
skeptics.article: Paul Singer: Bitcoin over gold? Are you crazy?!
skeptics.excerpt: There is no more reason to believe that bitcoin will stand the test of time than that governments will protect the value of government-created money, although bitcoin is newer and we always look at babies with hope.

skeptics.name: Robert J. Shiller
skeptics.title: Nobel Prize-winning Economist
skeptics.article: In Search of a Stable Electronic Currency
skeptics.excerpt: The Bitcoin phenomenon seems to fit the basic definition of a speculative bubble — that is, a special kind of fad, a mania for holding an asset in expectation of its appreciation.

skeptics.name: Nouriel Roubini
skeptics.title: Professor of Economics, New York University

skeptics.name: Warren Buffett
skeptics.title: Chairman & CEO, Berkshire Hathaway
skeptics.article: Buffett: ‘Stay Away’ From Bitcoin
skeptics.excerpt: "Stay away from it," he said, according to a transcript. "It’s a mirage basically."

skeptics.name: Anthony Watson & Halsey Minor
skeptics.title: CEO and Founder & Chairman, Uphold (formerly Bitreserve), respectively
skeptics.article: This bitcoin startup is changing its name and moving away from bitcoin
skeptics.excerpt:
Watson sounds even more negative on bitcoin. “I’ll be surprised if bitcoin is here in five years,” he has told Fortune. “The value of bitcoin isn’t the currency, but the technology. I think once the world becomes more accustomed and attuned to the platform of bitcoin, the noise will go away, and the currency will go away too.
[…]
Minor, too, predicts that bitcoin as a currency “will get destroyed.” He likens the coin’s current market cap—about $3.7 billion—to “an accounting mistake or rounding error that Bank of America makes.”

skeptics.name: Mike Hearn
skeptics.title: Lead Platform Engineer, R3CV
skeptics.article: The resolution of the Bitcoin experiment
skeptics.excerpt: But despite knowing that Bitcoin could fail all along, the now inescapable conclusion that it has failed still saddens me greatly. The fundamentals are broken and whatever happens to the price in the short term, the long term trend should probably be downwards. I will no longer be taking part in Bitcoin development and have sold all my coins.

skeptics.name: Vivek Wadhwa
skeptics.title: Contributor, The Washington Post; Tryhard
skeptics.article: R.I.P., Bitcoin. It’s time to move on.
skeptics.excerpt: Bitcoin did have great potential, but it is damaged beyond repair. A replacement is badly needed.

skeptics.name: Jeremy Allaire
skeptics.title: CEO, Circle
skeptics.article: Circle CEO Allaire: It’s Highly Unlikely We’ll Be Using Bitcoin in 5 or 10 Years
skeptics.excerpt: “Our view is that we’re still in the really early stages of the technology and its development,” said Allaire. “It’s highly unlikely that any of us will be using Bitcoin in five or ten years. In the same way that — how many of us use NCSA Mosaic or Netscape Navigator?”

skeptics.name: Timothy B. Lee
skeptics.title: Senior correspondent, technology and economics, Lead writer for "New Money", Vox Media
skeptics.article: Bitcoin was supposed to change the world. What happened?
skeptics.excerpt: What went wrong? The Bitcoin community has been hampered by a dysfunctional culture that has grown increasingly hostile toward experimentation. That has made it difficult for the Bitcoin network to keep up with changing market demands...Bitcoin's larger problem may be that it just doesn’t solve any problems normal people have.

skeptics.name: Dan McCrum
skeptics.title: Editor, Financial Times
skeptics.article: Bitcoin passes $1,000 but only number that matters is zero
skeptics.excerpt: As a phenomenon bitcoin has all the attributes of a pyramid scheme, requiring a constant influx of converts to push up the price, based on the promise of its use by future converts. So the ultimate value for bitcoin will be the same as all pyramid schemes: zero.

skeptics.name: Raoul Pal
skeptics.title: Macro Strategist, GMI
skeptics.article: Bitcoin Is Mania, Not a Store of Value… I Sold-Out Last Week
skeptics.excerpt: Bitcoin was supposed to be a store of value, you couldn’t mess with the formula… and now they are talking about a ‘hard fork’ changing it? Even if they don’t change the formula, the fact that they could? That’s enough to say it’s not a long-term store of value.

skeptics.name: Howard Marks
skeptics.title: Co-chairman, Oaktree Capital
skeptics.article: Billionaire investor Marks, who called the dotcom bubble, says bitcoin is a 'pyramid scheme'
skeptics.excerpt: In my view, digital currencies are nothing but an unfounded fad (or perhaps even a pyramid scheme), based on a willingness to ascribe value to something that has little or none beyond what people will pay for it.

skeptics.name: Al-Waleed Bin Talal bin Abdulaziz al Saud
skeptics.title: Citigroup shareholder
skeptics.article: Prince Alwaleed says bitcoin will implode: 'Enron in the making'
skeptics.excerpt: I just don't believe in this bitcoin thing. I think it's just going to implode one day. I think this is Enron in the making.
